## {.center}

::: {.r-fit-text}
Tool 1: Scientific Notation
:::

*Because the universe refuses to be written out in longhand*

---

## Scientific notation = brain-friendly compression

A number written as

$$a\times 10^n$$

means:

::: {.incremental}

- $a$ is the **coefficient** (usually between 1 and 10)
- $10^n$ tells you how many places the decimal moves
- $n$ is the **order of magnitude** (the scale)
:::

---

## Converting: decimal ‚Üî scientific notation

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="55%"}
**Big number**

$300{,}000{,}000;\text{m/s} = 3.0\times10^8;\text{m/s}$

**Small number**

$0.000000001;\text{s} = 1.0\times10^{-9};\text{s}$
:::

::: {.column width="45%"}
::: {.callout-tip appearance="minimal"}

### Direction rule

- $n>0$ ‚Üí move decimal **right** (bigger)
- $n<0$ ‚Üí move decimal **left** (smaller)
:::
:::
:::

---

## Operations (no calculator vibe)

::: {.incremental}

- Multiply: $(a\times10^m)(b\times10^n)=(ab)\times10^{m+n}$
- Divide: $\dfrac{a\times10^m}{b\times10^n}=\left(\dfrac{a}{b}\right)\times10^{m-n}$
- Powers: $(a\times10^m)^k = a^k\times10^{mk}$
:::

::: {.notes}
Make them say the rule out loud once. Muscle memory matters.
:::

## SI Prefixes: the language of scale

| Prefix | Symbol |    Factor |
| ------ | -----: | --------: |
| tera   |      T | $10^{12}$ |
| giga   |      G |  $10^{9}$ |
| mega   |      M |  $10^{6}$ |
| kilo   |      k |  $10^{3}$ |
| milli  |      m | $10^{-3}$ |
| micro  |  $\mu$ | $10^{-6}$ |
| nano   |      n | $10^{-9}$ |

::: {.notes}
Stress: these are *power-of-ten labels*. They‚Äôre not extra information; they are the exponent.
:::

---

## Order-of-magnitude estimation (ROM)

When exact arithmetic is annoying, estimate on purpose.

::: {.incremental}

- Round coefficients to nearby easy numbers.
- For a **rough order-of-magnitude**:
  - coefficient $<,3$ ‚Üí round to 1
  - coefficient $>,3$ ‚Üí round to 10
:::

::: {.callout-warning appearance="minimal"}
**ROM is not ‚Äúsloppy.‚Äù** It‚Äôs a controlled approximation for staying in the right cosmic zip code.
:::

::: {.r-fit-text}
Tool 2: Units & Conversions
:::

*Units are the meaning of a number*

## Units vs. Dimensions (very light intro)

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="55%"}
**Units** are human choices:

- meters vs kilometers vs AU

**Dimensions** are the *type* of quantity:

- length $[L]$, time $[T]$, mass $[M]$

Examples:

- speed: $[L/T]$
- area: $[L^2]$
- volume: $[L^3]$
:::

::: {.column width="45%"}
::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}

### Why mention dimensions?

Not to do a full ‚Äúdimension analysis‚Äù unit‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶but because **unit mistakes are the #1 avoidable error** in astronomy problems.
:::
:::
:::

---

## Conversion factors = ‚Äúmultiply by 1‚Äù

A conversion factor is an equality written as a fraction.

Example:

$$1,\text{m} \leftrightarrow 100,\text{cm}$$

so you can use

$$\frac{100,\text{cm}}{1,\text{m}}=1 \quad \text{or} \quad \frac{1,\text{m}}{100,\text{cm}}=1.$$

---

## The factor-label method (foolproof)

1. Write what you‚Äôre given.

2. Multiply by conversion factors arranged so **units cancel**.

3. Check that your final units match what you wanted.

::: {.callout-tip appearance="minimal"}

### Selection rule

Put the unit you want to **remove** in the denominator.
:::

---

## Example: minutes ‚Üí hours (structure, not memorization)

$$1000,\text{min}\times\frac{1,\text{hr}}{60,\text{min}};=;\frac{1000}{60},\text{hr}\approx 16.7,\text{hr}$$

::: {.fragment}
**Sanity check:** hours are bigger units than minutes, so the number should get smaller. ‚úì
:::

## Exponents matter in unit conversions

When a unit is squared or cubed, the conversion factor gets squared/cubed too.

Example idea:

$$1,\text{m}=100,\text{cm};\Rightarrow;1,\text{m}^3=(100,\text{cm})^3=10^6,\text{cm}^3.$$

::: {.notes}
This is a classic student trap. Do this once slowly.
:::

---

## Compound units (units built from units)

Some ‚Äúnamed‚Äù SI units are shortcuts:

::: {.incremental}

- $1,\text{N} = 1,\text{kg},\text{m}/\text{s}^2$
- $1,\text{J} = 1,\text{N},\text{m} = 1,\text{kg},\text{m}^2/\text{s}^2$
- $1,\text{W} = 1,\text{J}/\text{s} = 1,\text{kg},\text{m}^2/\text{s}^3$
:::

::: {.notes}
Tiny pitch: ‚ÄúIf the unit looks unfamiliar, rewrite it in base units.‚Äù
:::

:::

## Absolute vs. ratio (why ratios are magic)

Many physics relationships look like

$$A = k,B^n$$

Comparing two cases cancels $k$:

$$\frac{A_2}{A_1}=\left(\frac{B_2}{B_1}\right)^n.$$

::: {.fragment}
**Takeaway:** you learn the scaling story without hunting constants.
:::

---

## Scaling patterns you‚Äôll use all semester

| Scaling         | Meaning                  | Where it shows up                 |
| --------------- | ------------------------ | --------------------------------- |
| $\propto R^2$   | area grows fast          | telescope area, surface area      |
| $\propto R^3$   | volume grows *very* fast | planet volumes, ‚Äúhow many Earths‚Äù |
| $\propto 1/r^2$ | inverse-square           | brightness, gravity               |

## Inverse-square intuition (brightness)

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="55%"}
If you move twice as far from a light source:

$$\text{brightness}\propto \frac{1}{d^2}$$

$$\frac{B_2}{B_1}=\left(\frac{d_1}{d_2}\right)^2=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^2=\frac{1}{4}$$
:::

::: {.column width="45%"}
{{< img inverse-square-law >}}
:::
:::

::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}
This is why distance is *hard* in astronomy: small distance errors become big brightness errors.
:::

::: {.notes}
2 min. Draw attention to the diagram. Light spreads over area = 4œÄd¬≤.
Double the distance ‚Üí 4√ó the area ‚Üí 1/4 the brightness per unit area.
:::

## The rate template

Most rate problems are one equation with three rearrangements:

$$\text{amount} = \text{rate}\times\text{time}$$

So:

::: {.incremental}

- $\text{rate}=\dfrac{\text{amount}}{\text{time}}$
- $\text{time}=\dfrac{\text{amount}}{\text{rate}}$
- $\text{amount}=\text{rate}\times\text{time}$
:::

---

## Example: building a light-year (units + rate)

Light speed:

$$c\approx 3\times10^8,\text{m/s}$$

Seconds per year:

$$1,\text{yr}\approx 3.15\times10^7,\text{s}$$

So distance in one year:

$$1,\text{ly}=c\times(1,\text{yr})\approx (3\times10^8)(3.15\times10^7),\text{m}\approx 9.5\times10^{15},\text{m}.$$

---

## Putting it together: a problem-solving checklist

::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}

### The decoding ritual

For any quantitative astronomy question:
:::

::: {.incremental}

1. **What am I finding?** (write target with units)
2. **What am I given?** (write givens with units)
3. **Pick the tool:** conversion, ratio, or rate
4. **Do the unit cancellation** (this is your error detector)
5. **Sanity check:** bigger unit ‚Üí smaller number? right power of ten?
:::

## Solution 0 {#solution-0}

- $2,\text{AU}$: $2\times 8.3,\text{min}\approx 16.6,\text{min}$
- $0.5,\text{AU}$: $0.5\times 8.3,\text{min}\approx 4.15,\text{min}$

## Solution 1 {#solution-1}

1. $(3\times10^5)(4\times10^3) = 12\times10^{8} = 1.2\times10^9$

2. $(8\times10^7)/(2\times10^{12}) = 4\times10^{-5}$

3. $(2\times10^{-4})^3 = 2^3\times10^{-12}=8\times10^{-12}$

[‚Üê Back](#stop-solve-1)

## Solution 2 {#solution-2}

### A) $60,\text{mph} \to \text{m/s}$

$$60,\frac{\text{mile}}{\text{hr}}\times\frac{1.6,\text{km}}{1,\text{mile}}\times\frac{1000,\text{m}}{1,\text{km}}\times\frac{1,\text{hr}}{3600,\text{s}}\approx 26.7,\text{m/s}$$

### B) $0.5^\circ \to \text{arcsec}$

$$0.5^\circ\times\frac{60,\text{arcmin}}{1^\circ}\times\frac{60,\text{arcsec}}{1,\text{arcmin}}=1800,\text{arcsec}$$

[‚Üê Back](#stop-solve-2)

## Solution 3 {#solution-3}

$$109^3 \approx (1.09\times10^2)^3 = 1.09^3\times10^6\approx 1.3\times10^6.$$

So the Sun‚Äôs volume is about **1.3 million Earth volumes**.

## Solution 4 {#solution-4}

$$29.8,\text{km/s} = 2.98\times10^4,\text{m/s}$$

One minute is $60,\text{s}$, so

$$\text{distance}=vt=(2.98\times10^4,\text{m/s})(60,\text{s})\approx 1.79\times10^6,\text{m}.$$

That‚Äôs about **1800 km** in one minute.
